Exaggerate: The claim exaggerates the extent of baseball players kneeling to protest lynchings in the 1950s, as there is no evidence to support this.
Lack enough support: The claim lacks sufficient evidence or support to prove that baseball players in the 1950s were actually kneeling to protest lynchings.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that the photograph used as evidence is related to the protest, when in fact it is unrelated and taken from a different context.
Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the fact that the first black player did not join major league baseball until 1947, making it highly unlikely that white players were protesting on behalf of "negroes" in 1936.
Falters at times: The claim falters in providing accurate historical context, such as the absence of the national anthem during games in 1936 and the lack of spectators in the photograph.
Exist alternative explanation: The claim ignores alternative explanations for why baseball players were kneeling, such as the absence of any visible attendees standing or placing their hands over their hearts in the photograph.
